title: How to Make Rutabaga Fries

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries when they’re ready, set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to heat fully. Next, use a piece of parchment paper to line a large baking sheet for the fries. You can substitute foil for the parchment paper if you prefer. It’s important not to place the rutabaga fries directly on the baking sheet, though, because the edges will burn more quickly.

steps.headline: Peel and slice the rutabaga.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need a large rutabaga. Use a vegetable peeler to take off the skin, and then use a sharp knife to cut the rutabaga into strips that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. The exterior of some rutabagas are coated with wax to lock in the moisture. If yours has a waxy film, it may be easier to use a knife to peel it.

steps.headline: Toss the rutabaga fries with olive oil.
steps.description: After you’ve cut the rutabaga into slices, place the fries in a large bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and mix well so all of the fries are coated. If 1 tablespoon isn’t enough to coat all of the fries, drizzle in a little more until they’re all covered.

steps.headline: Mix in the salt, pepper, and lemon juice.
steps.description: When the fries are coated with the olive oil, add ⅛ teaspoon (¼ g) of pepper, ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of salt, and ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of lemon juice to the bowl. Toss all of the ingredients so the rutabaga fries are evenly seasoned. You can add whatever whatever seasonings that you like to the fries. Garlic powder, crushed red pepper, and dried oregano are tasty options.

steps.headline: Transfer the fries to the baking sheet.
steps.description: Once the rutabaga fries are seasoned, use tongs or a clean hand to place them on the lined baking sheet. Make sure that they are in a single layer so they’ll cook evenly.

steps.headline: Bake the fries until they are lightly browned.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet with the fries in the preheated oven. Allow them to cook for approximately 30 minutes, or until the fries are a light brown color. To ensure that the rutabaga fries cook evenly, turn them over every 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the fries warm.
steps.description: When the rutabaga fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Allow the fries to cool for 3 to 5 minutes, and then transfer them to a platter or dish. Serve them while they are still warm. You can pair the rutabaga fries with your favorite dipping sauce, such as ketchup, garlic aioli, or ranch dressing.

methods.name: Preparing Garlic and Rosemary Rutabaga Fries

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the baking sheets.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is ready to bake the fries, set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully preheat. Next, line two large baking sheets with parchment paper so the fries won’t stick. If you prefer, you can line the baking sheets with silicone baking mats.

steps.headline: Peel and cut the rutabaga into strips.
steps.description: The fries require one large rutabaga. Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler, and cut it into long, thin strips as you would with a potato French fries. Instead of one large rutabaga, you can use a couple of smaller ones. You can cut the fries to any thickness that you like, but a ½-inch (13-mm) thick is the usual size.

steps.headline: Combine the fries with the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description: Place the rutabaga in a large bowl. Add 1 ½ tablespoons (22 ½ ml)  of olive oil, 3 sprigs of fresh, chopped rosemary, 2 minced garlic cloves, ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of salt, and ¼ teaspoon (½ g) of freshly ground black pepper. Mix well so the fries are evenly coated with the seasonings. If you prefer a stronger garlic flavor, you can add more cloves of fresh garlic.

steps.headline: Divide the fries between the two baking sheets.
steps.description: Once all of the rutabaga fries are coated with the seasonings, arrange them on the lined baking sheets. Spread half of the fries on one of the sheets and the other half on the other sheet so all of the fries are in single layer. If you don’t have two baking sheets, you can bake the rutabaga fries in two batches.

steps.headline: Bake the fries for half an hour.
steps.description: When the fries are on the baking sheets, place them in the oven. Allow the fries to bake for about 30 to 40 minutes or until they are crispy. Be sure to turn the fries every 10 minutes so they don’t burn.

steps.headline: Season the fries with salt and serve warm.
steps.description: When the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Sprinkle a little more salt over them if desired, and transfer to a plate to serve. The fries pair well with simple ketchup or creamy dipping sauces, such as a parmesan aioli.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line the baking sheets.
steps.description: Prepare the oven for baking the fries by setting the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allowing it to fully preheat. Next, line two baking sheets with foil. You can substitute parchment paper for the foil if you prefer.

steps.headline: Peel and slice the rutabaga.
steps.description: You’ll need a large rutabaga to make the fries. Take off its skin with a vegetable peeler or knife, and use a sharp knife to cut the vegetable into strips in your desired length and thickness. It’s best if the fries aren’t larger than ½-inch (13-mm) thick.

steps.headline: Combine the rutabaga fries with the remaining ingredients.
steps.description: Transfer the fries to a bowl, and add 1 ½ tablespoons (22 ½ ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic salt, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of smoked paprika, ½ teaspoon (1 g) of cayenne pepper, and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of ground red chipotle. Toss the fries with the seasonings to ensure that they’re evenly coated. You can adjust the amount of each seasoning to suit your taste and make the fries as spicy or smoky as you like. For spicier fries, add more cayenne pepper and ground chipotle. For a smokier fries, add more paprika.

steps.headline: Transfer the fries to the baking sheets.
steps.description: When the fries are seasoned, place them on the lined baking sheets. Divide them evenly between the two sheets so all of the fries are arranged in a single layer.

steps.headline: Bake the fries until they are crispy.
steps.description: Place the cookie sheets in the preheated oven. Let the fries bake for 30 to 40 minutes or until they are crispy. The fries can burn quickly, so when you reach the 30 minute mark of baking, check them every 5 minutes to see if they’re done.

steps.headline: Serve the fries while still warm.
steps.description: When the fries are done, remove the baking sheets from the oven. Allow the rutabaga fries to cool on the sheets for about 5 minutes before transferring them to a platter while still warm for serving. Because the fries are spicy, they pair best with a creamy dipping sauce, such a ranch dressing.

text: Whipping Up Basic Rutabaga Fries Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries when they’re ready, set the temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to heat fully. Next, use a piece of parchment paper to line a large baking sheet for the fries. You can substitute foil for the parchment paper if you prefer. It’s important not to place the rutabaga fries directly on the baking sheet, though, because the edges will burn more quickly. Peel and slice the rutabaga. For the fries, you’ll need a large rutabaga. Use a vegetable peeler to take off the skin, and then use a sharp knife to cut the rutabaga into strips that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. The exterior of some rutabagas are coated with wax to lock in the moisture. If yours has a waxy film, it may be easier to use a knife to peel it. Toss the rutabaga fries with olive oil. After you’ve cut the rutabaga into slices, place the fries in a large bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and mix well so all of the fries are coated. If 1 tablespoon isn’t enough to coat all of the fries, drizzle in a little more until they’re all covered. Mix in the salt, pepper, and lemon juice. When the fries are coated with the olive oil, add ⅛ teaspoon (¼ g) of pepper, ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of salt, and ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of lemon juice to the bowl. Toss all of the ingredients so the rutabaga fries are evenly seasoned. You can add whatever whatever seasonings that you like to the fries. Garlic powder, crushed red pepper, and dried oregano are tasty options. Transfer the fries to the baking sheet. Once the rutabaga fries are seasoned, use tongs or a clean hand to place them on the lined baking sheet. Make sure that they are in a single layer so they’ll cook evenly. Bake the fries until they are lightly browned. Place the baking sheet with the fries in the preheated oven. Allow them to cook for approximately 30 minutes, or until the fries are a light brown color. To ensure that the rutabaga fries cook evenly, turn them over every 10 minutes. Serve the fries warm. When the rutabaga fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Allow the fries to cool for 3 to 5 minutes, and then transfer them to a platter or dish. Serve them while they are still warm. You can pair the rutabaga fries with your favorite dipping sauce, such as ketchup, garlic aioli, or ranch dressing. Preparing Garlic and Rosemary Rutabaga Fries Preheat the oven and prepare the baking sheets. To ensure that the oven is ready to bake the fries, set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully preheat. Next, line two large baking sheets with parchment paper so the fries won’t stick. If you prefer, you can line the baking sheets with silicone baking mats. Peel and cut the rutabaga into strips. The fries require one large rutabaga. Remove the skin with a vegetable peeler, and cut it into long, thin strips as you would with a potato French fries. Instead of one large rutabaga, you can use a couple of smaller ones. You can cut the fries to any thickness that you like, but a ½-inch (13-mm) thick is the usual size. Combine the fries with the rest of the ingredients. Place the rutabaga in a large bowl. Add 1 ½ tablespoons (22 ½ ml)  of olive oil, 3 sprigs of fresh, chopped rosemary, 2 minced garlic cloves, ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, ¼ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of salt, and ¼ teaspoon (½ g) of freshly ground black pepper. Mix well so the fries are evenly coated with the seasonings. If you prefer a stronger garlic flavor, you can add more cloves of fresh garlic. Divide the fries between the two baking sheets. Once all of the rutabaga fries are coated with the seasonings, arrange them on the lined baking sheets. Spread half of the fries on one of the sheets and the other half on the other sheet so all of the fries are in single layer. If you don’t have two baking sheets, you can bake the rutabaga fries in two batches. Bake the fries for half an hour. When the fries are on the baking sheets, place them in the oven. Allow the fries to bake for about 30 to 40 minutes or until they are crispy. Be sure to turn the fries every 10 minutes so they don’t burn. Season the fries with salt and serve warm. When the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Sprinkle a little more salt over them if desired, and transfer to a plate to serve. The fries pair well with simple ketchup or creamy dipping sauces, such as a parmesan aioli. Baking Spicy Rutabaga Fries Preheat the oven and line the baking sheets. Prepare the oven for baking the fries by setting the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allowing it to fully preheat. Next, line two baking sheets with foil. You can substitute parchment paper for the foil if you prefer. Peel and slice the rutabaga. You’ll need a large rutabaga to make the fries. Take off its skin with a vegetable peeler or knife, and use a sharp knife to cut the vegetable into strips in your desired length and thickness. It’s best if the fries aren’t larger than ½-inch (13-mm) thick. Combine the rutabaga fries with the remaining ingredients. Transfer the fries to a bowl, and add 1 ½ tablespoons (22 ½ ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic salt, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of smoked paprika, ½ teaspoon (1 g) of cayenne pepper, and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of ground red chipotle. Toss the fries with the seasonings to ensure that they’re evenly coated. You can adjust the amount of each seasoning to suit your taste and make the fries as spicy or smoky as you like. For spicier fries, add more cayenne pepper and ground chipotle. For a smokier fries, add more paprika. Transfer the fries to the baking sheets. When the fries are seasoned, place them on the lined baking sheets. Divide them evenly between the two sheets so all of the fries are arranged in a single layer. Bake the fries until they are crispy. Place the cookie sheets in the preheated oven. Let the fries bake for 30 to 40 minutes or until they are crispy. The fries can burn quickly, so when you reach the 30 minute mark of baking, check them every 5 minutes to see if they’re done. Serve the fries while still warm. When the fries are done, remove the baking sheets from the oven. Allow the rutabaga fries to cool on the sheets for about 5 minutes before transferring them to a platter while still warm for serving. Because the fries are spicy, they pair best with a creamy dipping sauce, such a ranch dressing.
